title: Peking–Mukden Railway
text:
Peking–Mukden Railway () was a 19th century <a href="Steam%20locomotive">steam powered</a> trunkline connecting Peking (<a href="Beijing">Beijing</a>) and Mukden (former name of <a href="Shenyang">Shenyang</a>) through <a href="Tianjin">Tianjin</a>, northeastern <a href="Hebei">Hebei</a>, and southwestern <a href="Liaoning">Liaoning</a>; it was a crucial railway in <a href="North%20China">North China</a> and <a href="Northeast%20China">Northeast China</a>.
The history of the railway can date back to <a href="Kaiping%20Tramway%20and%20Imperial%20Railways%20of%20North%20China">Kaiping Tramway</a> (often known as Tangshan-Xugezhuang Railway in Chinese) completed in 1881, which became PMR after several extensions in the next 31 years. It was significant and influential in the Railway development and even transportation histories in China since it was the first trunk line being built and operated successfully. Although <a href="Woosung%20Road">Woosung Road</a> and had been built years before PMR, they were neither built for practical use nor in operation for more than a year.
Timeline.
The timeline of how <a href="Kaiping%20Tramway%20and%20Imperial%20Railways%20of%20North%20China">Kaiping Tramway</a> was transformed into the trunkline PMR was shown below.
The Inner-Pass section.
Predecessor - Kaiping Tramway.
<a href="Kaiping%20Tramway%20and%20Imperial%20Railways%20of%20North%20China">Kaiping Tramway</a>, commonly known as Tangshan-Xugezhuang Railway in China, was the first railway built for transportation purpose and was regarded as the origin of <a href="Rail%20transport%20in%20China">China's railway development</a>. With the length of about 9 km, this railway was completed in November, 1881 as a <a href="Tramway%20%28industrial%29">tramway</a> to help the coals in <a href="Kaiping%20Mines">Kaiping Mines</a> move to Tangshan to meet the demands of <a href="Imperial%20Chinese%20Navy">Imperial Chinese Navy</a> and <a href="China%20Merchants%20Group">China Merchants Steam Navigation Company</a>. As the supply of Kaiping Mines increased, this tramway was extended to <a href="lutai">lutai</a> and renamed as Tangshan-Lutai Railway in 1887.
Conversion to trunk line.
On March 5, 1887, The Administrative of <a href="Imperial%20Chinese%20Navy">Imperial Chinese Navy</a> reported to <a href="Royal%20court">Royal court</a>, requesting for railway's further extension to <a href="Taku%20Forts">Taku</a> in the west and <a href="Shanhai%20Pass">Shanhai Pass</a> in the east, to make troops move faster. <a href="Claude%20W.%20Kinder">Claude W. Kinder</a> was called upon to survey the route. Li had to overcome opposition in the Imperial Court... but gained sanction for the line to be extended 50 miles to <a href="Tianjin">Tianjin</a>. Kinder, as Chief Engineer of the now newly named China Railway Company, was then permitted to secure the services of several more foreign engineers which included Resident Engineers A.W.H. Bellingham and W. Watson.
The railway was extended from Lutai to Taku in March 1888, and to Tianjin in August. Having been built for 14 months, the railway was completed and renamed as Tangshan-Tianjin Railway. Limited train services commenced in August 1888. On October 9, the opening ceremony of Tangshan-Tianjin Railway, presented by <a href="Zhili">Zhili</a> Governor <a href="Zhou%20Fu">Zhou Fu</a>, was held in Tianjin. After examining the quality of the equipments in person, <a href="Li%20Hongzhang">Li Hongzhang</a> said that "the railway from Tianjin to Tangshan is steady, and the bridges and stations are all built in compliances with technical requirements". At this point, the length of this railway was extended to 130km. The cost of the construction of the extension to Tianjin was 12.4 thousand silver Tael per km and 1.5 million silver Tael in total.
Imperial Court opposed the western extension while sanctioned the northern extension. Under the permission and the demand of transportation from the new-built colliery at Linxi, <a href="Guye%20District">Guye</a>, the railway reached Guye in late 1890, <a href="Luanzhou">Lanchou</a> in 1892, and <a href="Shanhaiguan%20District">Shanhaiguan</a> in 1894, during which period the line was transferred to the control of a newly formed Imperial Chinese Railway Administration (Chinese: 北洋官铁路局).
It was during this period of expansion that <a href="Jeme%20Tien%20Yow">Jeme Tien Yow</a> joined the railway company in 1888 as a cadet engineer under Kinder's supervision. Kinder highly appreciated the talents of this Yale-graduated engineer and Jeme was soon promoted first to Resident and then District Engineer. In all Jeme spent 12 years working on various sections of this railway.
Predecessor - Tientsin-Lugou Bridge Railway.
Tientsin-<a href="Marco%20Polo%20Bridge">Lugou Bridge</a> Railway was built from 1895 to 1897 as a mark of reform in the Royal Court. With the length of 150km, this railway connected <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a>, <a href="langfang">langfang</a> (in <a href="hebei">hebei</a>), and <a href="tianjin">tianjin</a>.
Extension.
In 1901, the extension line was built to connect Ma Chiu Pu to <a href="Zhengyangmen">Zhengyangmen</a>. When it was completed, the section in Beijing extended along the border between occupation zones controlled by British and German; specifically, the line extended eastward to <a href="Yongdingmen">Yung Ting Men</a> and the <a href="Temple%20of%20Heaven">Temple of Heaven</a>, turned northward to , and turned westward to <a href="Zhengyangmen">Zhengyangmen</a>.
The construction of outer-Pass section.
Planning.
At the beginning of 1890, <a href="Zongli%20Yamen">Zongli Yamen</a> suggested railway construction in <a href="Northeast%20China">Northeast China</a> to resist <a href="Empire%20of%20Japan">Japan</a>'s lust on <a href="Korean%20Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>. In April, <a href="Hong%20Jun">Hong Jun</a>, the Envoy to <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a>, reported Russian's plan of <a href="Trans-Siberian%20Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a>, making the Royal Court shocked. To eliminate the potential territorial threats, the Royal Court suspended the construction of <a href="Beijing%E2%80%93Hankou%20railway">Beijing–Hankou railway</a> and ordered <a href="Li%20Hongzhang">Li Hongzhang</a> to "prepare well" the Kwantung Railway from <a href="Yingkou">Yingkou</a> to <a href="Jilin%20City">Jilin City</a> and <a href="Hunchun">Hunchun</a>. Then, Li sent 2 engineers, Kinder and Cox, to examine the landform. When they came back in November, Li told <a href="Imperial%20Chinese%20Navy">Navy</a> Administrative that the railway proposed faced huge difficulties in construction and potential low revenue because of the sparse population; moreover, this plan might create tension in <a href="History%20of%20Sino-Russian%20relations">Sino-Russian relations</a>. Instead, Li proposed another route from Guye to <a href="Shenyang">Shengjing</a> and Jilin City, which was approved in early 1891. When the second land surveying team came back, the details of the route were confirmed as from Shanhai Pass to <a href="Jinzhou">Jinzhou</a>, <a href="Xinmin%2C%20Liaoning">Xinmin</a>, <a href="Shenyang">Shengjing</a>, and <a href="Jilin">Jilin</a>. In March 1891, Li Hongzhang reported the details of Kwantung Railway, including the methods of construction and the modification on the route, to the Royal Courts; besides, he requested the funds for Beijing-Hankou Railway - 2 million Silver Teal annually - for the construction of Kwantung Railway. The plan was approved on March 13th and Official Railway Bureau of Imperial North China was founded afterward. This was the first time the government preside railway construction.
Construction.
Plans to continue the railway North-eastwards beyond Shan Hai Kuan ("Shanhaiguan") to <a href="Jinzhou">Jinzhou</a>, <a href="Shenyang">Shenyang</a> and <a href="Jilin">Jilin</a> were set back by the lack of funds and because of <a href="First%20Sino-Japanese%20War">First Sino-Japanese War</a> (August 1894 to March 1895). By 1896 the rails had only reached Chung Ho So (pinyin: "Zhonghousuo" 中后所, nowadays <a href="Suizhong%20County">Suizhong County</a>), 40 miles beyond Shan Hai Kuan. China's loss of the war with Japan brought about Li Hung Chang's disgrace and virtual removal from power, and with this came new management. After a short power struggle between rival factions, <a href="Sheng%20Xuanhuai">Sheng Hsuan Huai</a> succeeded in gaining control of this new organization and appointed his own supporters to the directorate. Among them, the most prominent was (), who was appointed Director-General and made responsible for all sections of the Railway.
During the period 1898-9 a British loan of £2,300,000 was negotiated and an issue of bonds raised in London for the purpose of extending this line northwards to <a href="Xinmin%2C%20Liaoning">Xinmin</a> and a branch line from <a href="Goubangzi">Koupangtzu</a> to <a href="Yingkou">Yingkou</a>. The loan was arranged by the British and Chinese Corporation, a joint venture and front for the <a href="The%20Hongkong%20and%20Shanghai%20Banking%20Corporation">Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation</a> and <a href="Jardine%20Matheson">Jardine Matheson and Company</a>. In spite of objections from the Russians (who were themselves busy grabbing control of Chinese territory in Manchuria) the line to <a href="Jinzhou">Chinchou</a> was eventually completed in 1899.
On July 31, 1897, the bureaus of Tientsin-Lugou Bridge Railway and Tientsin-Yu Pass Railway merged and formed new Trans-Pass Railway.
Under the control of foreign power, a small port was developed at <a href="Qinhuangdao">Qinhuangdao</a> with a six-mile branch line joining the mainline a few miles southwest of Shan Hai Kuan at Tangho.
In April 1902, the Russian Empire signed the Treaty of Recession(Chinese:); afterward, the Russian government agreed to recall troops in 3 phases and returned the outer-Pass (Shanhai Pass-Yingkou-<a href="Dahushan%20railway%20station">Dahushan</a>) section. In exchange, the Qing Royal Court agreed to consult Russia about the construction of railways in the south part of <a href="Northeast%20China">Northeast China</a>. However, the Russian government broke their words and only receded to the east bank of <a href="Liao%20River">Liao River</a>; moreover, they showed their disagreement with the construction of Liao River Bridge by citing the <a href="Convention%20for%20the%20Lease%20of%20the%20Liaotung%20Peninsula">Convention for the Lease of the Liaotung Peninsula</a>. Under this situation, the outer-pass section can only be extended 89 km to <a href="Xinmin%2C%20Liaoning">Xinmin</a> in 1904; thence, the length of this railway reached 773 km.
Xinmin Tramway issue.
The Russian troops' refusal of withdrawal intensified <a href="Japan%E2%80%93Russia%20relations">the rivalry between Japan and Russia</a> and caused the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo-Japanese War</a>. Weak in military forces, the Chinese government had no choice but to announce the region east of Liao River as "Battlefield" and "<a href="Neutral%20country">Neutrality</a>". However, the Japanese forces went beyond the line by quartering in Xinmin (located west of Liao River) and built the narrow-gauge (<a href="2%20ft%20and%20600%20mm%20gauge%20railways">2 ft</a> to <a href="3%20ft%206%20in%20gauge%20railways">3.5 ft</a>) tramway from Xinmin to <a href="Huanggutun%20railway%20station">Huanggutun railway station</a>, aka. Xinmin–Fengtian Tramway. The protests from Chinese officials, though for several times, were ignored.
In 1907 this extension was purchased by Imperial Railways of North China at a price of 1.66 million <a href="Japanese%20yen">Japanese yen</a> and the agreement that should be funded by Japanese. The conversion to <a href="Standard-gauge%20railway">Standard-gauge railway</a> was finished in the same year, and the construction of Liao River Bridge was finished in 1908.
Reaching Mukden downtown.
When the war ended, the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Portsmouth">Treaty of Portsmouth</a> was signed and the South Manchuria branch of the <a href="Chinese%20Eastern%20Railway">Chinese Eastern Railway</a> was transferred to Japan's control and renamed as <a href="South%20Manchuria%20Railway">South Manchuria Railway</a>. To extend further, the Trans-Pass Railway had to pass by <a href="South%20Manchuria%20Railway%20Zone">the surrounding areas of SMR</a>. After years of negotiation, the Chinese and Japanese governments signed the Agreement of Peking-Mukden Railway extension, in which China allowed Japan to build the branch line from <a href="Dashiqiao">Dashiqiao</a> to <a href="Yingkou">Yingkou</a>, and Japan, in exchange, allowed PMR to go under SMR near <a href="Huanggutun%20railway%20station">Huanggutun railway station</a> and reach the downtown of Mukden. This extension was completed on December 20, 1911, and a new Mukden Station opened near Xiaoximen, which was renovated by <a href="Yang%20Tingbao">Yang Tingbao</a> to the biggest station in the city - <a href="Shenyang%20North%20railway%20station">Shenyang North railway station</a> in 1927
Destructions brought by wars.
The <a href="Boxer%20Uprising">Boxer Uprising</a> of 1900 brought a complete halt to railway construction progress and total destruction of large sections of the existing railway in around Peking and Tientsin. The railway's appointed new Managing-Director, <a href="Xu%20Jingcheng">Hsu Ching Cheng</a> (pinyin: Xu Jingcheng 許景澄), was executed for being "too pro-foreign". Moreover, <a href="Fengtai%20railway%20station">Fengtai</a> and were destructed by boxers. During <a href="Siege%20of%20the%20International%20Legations">the invasion of the Eight-Nation Alliance</a>, Russian troops sieged the section from <a href="Tianjin%20railway%20station">Tianjin railway station</a> to <a href="Yangcun%20railway%20station">Yangcun railway station</a>, while the British troops were trying to take over this section. During the resistance, the Chinese army and <a href="Boxer%20Rebellion">Boxers</a> attacked Tianjin Station rigorously and dismantled the section from <a href="Tanggu%20District">Tanggu</a> to Beijing. On January 17, 1901, after negotiations, the Russian troops receded to the east of <a href="Shanhai%20Pass">the Pass</a> and took away equipment, including machines and rolling stocks, from the railway and affiliated factories on their way. On September 7, after the <a href="Boxer%20Protocol">Boxer Protocol</a> was signed, <a href="Eight-Nation%20Alliance">the foreign states involved</a> were approved to quarter near the railway and stations. In August 1902, the Chinese government reclaimed administrative power from British and Russian troops. However, before the reclamation, the Chinese government signed, with the British government, the Agreements after the Handover of Trans-Pass, which yielded the administrative power <a href="de%20facto">de facto</a> to the British. 
On January 4, 1912, days after the outbreak of <a href="Xinhai%20Revolution">Xinhai Revolution</a>, the uprising forces were going to the west of the Shanhai Pass by train and hit hard in <a href="Luanzhou">Luanzhou</a> by <a href="Cao%20Kun">Cao Kun</a>, Wang Huaiqing, and their reinforcements from <a href="Shijiazhuang">Shijiazhuang</a>
On June 4, 1928, <a href="Zhang%20Zuolin">Zhang Zuolin</a>, the last leader of <a href="Beiyang%20government">Beiyang government</a>, en route back to Mukden, was <a href="Huanggutun%20incident">assassinated near Huanggutun Station</a> by dynamites planted by <a href="Kwantung%20Army">Kwantung Army</a>.
Split.
After <a href="Mukden%20Incident">Mukden Incident</a>, on January 7, 1932, supported by <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Army">Imperial Japanese Army</a>, <a href="Manchukuo">Manchukuo</a> sieged the outer-Pass section, transferred to SMR's control, and renamed it as Mukden-<a href="Shanhaiguan%20railway%20station">Shanhaiguan</a> Railway, while the inner-Pass section was renamed as <a href="Beijing%E2%80%93Shanhaiguan%20railway">Beijing–Shanhaiguan railway</a> and controlled afterwards. After the <a href="Marco%20Polo%20Bridge%20Incident">Marco Polo Bridge Incident</a>, the Beijing–Shanhaiguan railway was taken control by <a href="North%20China%20Transportation%20Company">North China Transportation Company</a>
Operation.
Administration.
Following the relief of the besieged foreign legations in Peking by <a href="Eight-Nation%20Alliance">an international allied expeditionary force</a>, the Chinese government lost control of what remained of the badly damaged railway system for a two-year period of <a href="Siege%20of%20the%20International%20Legations">allied foreign occupation</a>. British and other foreign military units repaired the line between Tientsin and Peking (1900–1902) and the railway was also extended from the Ma Chiu Pu terminus to new Peking stations. What was built first was <a href="Trams%20in%20Beijing%23History%20of%20old%20trams">the tramway</a> from Ma Chiu Pu to Yong Ding Men by the British in December 1900. For two years (1900–1902) the inner-pass section of this railway was under the overall command of a British army "Royal Engineers" contingent using the name "British Railway Administration" (BRA) while the outer-pass section (from <a href="Shanhai%20Pass">Shanhai Pass</a> to <a href="Xinmin%2C%20Liaoning">Xinmin</a>) was controlled by Russians until returned to China on September 29, 1902. During the BRA period, the railway operated a traveling post office train and a special overprinted Chinese postal stamp was introduced for mailing letters carried by the BRA's express mail trains.
After civilian control of the railway was resumed in late 1902, Claude Kinder was reinstated as Chief Engineer and also given additional and more powerful responsibilities as General Manager. Strongman <a href="Yuan%20Shikai">Yuan Shikai</a> had himself appointed as Director-General of Railways and Kinder's former boss, Hu Yu-fen, who had been ousted in 1899, came back to power as the Assistant Director-General. The Chinese railway administration also had the services of a bright Western-educated new Secretary, returned Chinese Educational Mission student Liang Ju Hao (pinyin: "Liang Ruhao" 梁汝浩), better known to Europeans as M.T. Liang.
